nodes.body:
### Context
Trying to configure the `JacocoReport` with the  [Junit 5](https://junit.org/junit5/) plugin is fraught with peril unless you know exactly what you are doing.
If you want to configure the Junit 5 test task with the current API a naive user would think that this is enough (hint, I was that naive user):

```kotlin
val junitPlatformTest: JavaExec by tasks
val sourceSets = java.sourceSets

task<JacocoReport>("jacocoJunit5TestReport") {
    executionData(junitPlatformTest)
    dependsOn(junitPlatformTest)

    sourceSets(sourceSets["main"])
    sourceDirectories = files(sourceSets["main"].allSource.srcDirs)
    classDirectories = files(sourceSets["main"].output)
    reports {
        html.isEnabled = true
        xml.isEnabled = true
        csv.isEnabled = false
    }
}
```

However, this doesn't work (it fails silently) because you need to first bootstrap the `junitPlatformTest` task by calling `jacoco { applyTo(junitPlatformTest) }`. This results in the following code being required to configure it correctly:

```
val junitPlatformTest: JavaExec by tasks

jacoco {
    applyTo(junitPlatformTest)
}

val sourceSets = java.sourceSets

task<JacocoReport>("jacocoJunit5TestReport") {
    executionData(junitPlatformTest)
    dependsOn(junitPlatformTest)

    sourceSets(sourceSets["main"])
    sourceDirectories = files(sourceSets["main"].allSource.srcDirs)
    classDirectories = files(sourceSets["main"].output)
    reports {
        html.isEnabled = true
        xml.isEnabled = true
        csv.isEnabled = false
    }
}
```

The attached change should make it easier to immediately spot this problem when configuring jacoco.

I haven't attached tests but if you think it would be helpful to add a test that this gets logged, I can.

Signed-off-by: Martin Vehovsky <vehovsky@gmail.com>

### Context
I believe it fixes following issues:
#1397 SNAPSHOT version are not searched across repositories
#1737 Treat Maven snapshot dependencies as dynamic versions

This will greatly improve workflow when you have coexisting Gradle and Maven projects. Especially when your Gradle project depends on SNAPSHOT version of Maven project that can't be for whatever reason converted to Gradle. You will now be able to resolve 'latest' version of the snapshot (changing module) from local maven repository or remote repo.
 

### Comments
The main change, that forced me to do certain alignments in integration tests is that for local maven repositories metadata file name is _maven-metadata-local.xml_ instead of _maven-metadata.xml_ [see Maven doc](http://maven.apache.org/ref/3.3.9/maven-repository-metadata/).

I also needed to know when to stop looking for the 'latest' snapshot (changing module), that is when the snapshot is resolved from remote repository.

Apart of units there are two new integration tests verifying the behaviour:
 - resolve and cache latest snapshot from remote
 - resolve latest snapshot from local

nodes.body:
### Context

This pull requests makes test xml suites for TestNG runnable in parallel through a single task, enabling fine-grained control of test execution in parallel, forked JVMs.

Fixes [Issue: #2783 - The use of TestNG suites in combination with maxParallelForks causes tests to be execute multiple times](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/2783).

I think this pull request is a nice first stab at fixing the problem, but I'm not familiar enough with the codebase to say that it's the correct way. I'm willing to implement it differently if need be.

My personal use case is that I work on a legacy project, and certain tests are not allowed to run in parallel within the same JVM. 
These tests are in the same module however, and I'd like to speed up our tests by runnign them in parallel in separate JVMs, but cannot, since they are in the same gradle project.

#### Background

When using TestNG in with gradle, there are two configuration options: 

##### 1) Configure TestNG & class scanning through gradle. 

This is generally the preferred method as it easily grants access to things like parallelization, rerunning tasks first, and other gradle driven enhancements.

##### 2) Specify or build suite xml files for TestNG to use. 

This (in my mind) is usually for legacy projects that need finer grained control. A major draw back is that you cannot run the xml files in parallel JVMs.

The way xml files are handled currently doesn't play well with setting max parallel forks. 
The root cause is that the xml files would get passed to every test executor fork as they are created, and get executed one per test executor.

This initial fix moves test suite xml tracking from the test class processor creation to be handled more like test classes - passed around between the executors so they can be assigned one by one. 
That fixes [Issue: #2783](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/2783) in the following ways

 1) When one test suite is specified but maxForks > 1, the suite gets executed a single executor only once
 2) When more than one test suite is specified and maxForks > 1, the test suites get assigned round-robin to the test executor, before they are run.
 3) When maxForks = 1, things behave as they have been behaving

### Context
See gradle/gradle-native#399.

/cc @lacasseio

`sourceCompatibility` is added to the new C++ plugins for the GCC and Clang toolchains, enabling users to declare a C++ binary's source compatibility. The introduced source compatibilities are `Cpp98`, `Cpp03`, `Cpp11`, `Cpp17`, and `Cpp2a`. The `CppSourceCompatibility` enum will have to be updated with any future compatibilities. In addition, `GccVersionCppSourceCompatibility` and `ClangVersionCppSourceCompatibility` encapsulate the logic that translates a `CppSourceCompatibility` into the correct command-line argument for the compiler. This requires knowledge of the compiler's version.

Issue: #3987

### Context
On windows, when a process exit and leave child processes running, gradle Exec tasks are stuck. This is because the output stream is not closed until child process exit.
Proposed solution times out and disconnects 1 second after the process exit if the stream is not closed. This should enough to handle remaining output.

Fixes #9950

### Context
<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
<!--- Link to relevant issues or forum discussions here -->

This fix enables cross-compiling native Cpp libraries using the CppLibraryPlugin. Previously, the CppLibraryPlugin did not allow targeting builds for operating systems other than the host (see `Dimensions.tryToBuildOnHost()`).

https://github.com/gradle/gradle-native/issues/989
https://github.com/gradle/gradle-native/issues/1020
https://github.com/gradle/gradle-native/issues/992
https://github.com/gradle/gradle-native/issues/487

This change allows setting up cross-compile builds. For example:

```
plugins {
    id 'cpp-library'
}

model {
    toolChains {

        android_clang(Clang) {
            target('android_armv7') {
                path '/data/apps/android-toolchain-arm/bin/'
                cCompiler.executable = 'arm-linux-androideabi-gcc'
                cppCompiler.executable = 'arm-linux-androideabi-g++'
                linker.executable = 'arm-linux-androideabi-g++'
                staticLibArchiver.executable = 'arm-linux-androideabi-ar'
                stripper.executable = 'arm-linux-androideabi-strip'
            }
        }

        mingw(Gcc) {
            target('linux_x86-64')

            target('windows_x86-64') {
                cCompiler.executable = 'x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc'
                cppCompiler.executable = 'x86_64-w64-mingw32-g++'
                linker.executable = 'x86_64-w64-mingw32-ld'
                staticLibArchiver.executable = 'x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar'
            }

            target('windows_x86') {
                cCompiler.executable = 'i686-w64-mingw32-gcc'
                cppCompiler.executable = 'i686-w64-mingw32-g++'
                linker.executable = 'i686-w64-mingw32-ld'
                staticLibArchiver.executable = 'i686-w64-mingw32-ar'
            }
        }
    }
}

library {
    targetMachines = [
        machines.os('linux').architecture('x86-64'),
        machines.os('windows').architecture('x86-64'),
        machines.os('android').architecture('armv7')
    ]
}

```

This example creates `assembleLinuxX86-64`, `assembleWindowsX86-64`, and `assembleAndroidArmv7` tasks.

nodes.body:
Adds support for declaring branches on Ivy dependencies.

Issue: #1357

### Context

This is a long-standing feature request, in the issue linked above. When using existing Ivy repositories with branches, it is a necessity. 

It turned out to be a lot more involved than simply supporting a `[branch]` field in the Ivy resource patterns. The branch has to be part of the module metadata used in dependency resolution, cache serialization, transitive Ivy dependencies, etc.

### Status

My changes seem to work OK for our projects. I can now declare a dependency like this:
```
    runtime(group="metaswitch", branch="diameter/trunk", name="diameter-base", version="latest.integration", configuration="impl")
```
But it feels like what I've done could be cleaner. (I think there are too many `instanceof` checks for example.)

I didn't want to add a field/accessor for the branch to the core API interfaces, or the default implementations, because this is something Ivy-specific so belongs in Ivy-specific classes. But it was hard to pass the branch to the places it needed to get without doing that. And a lot of the time there was no factory method, and no nice way to decide which type of identifier or selector to create. Hence the somewhat ugly instanceof checks and checks for the existence of a branch scattered throughout.

I've yet to add tests for these changes. I'm creating this PR to get some feedback on what I've done so far (after commenting on the issue). Possibly I've missed some obvious way to implement it more nicely. Perhaps I should have just changed the default implementation classes? I'm very keen to work through whatever is needed to get this into a release.

I am aware of issue #1386, but I decided I needed to focus on branches, at least for this first attempt. It could be that what I've done can be extended into other extra attributes, but I haven't looked at it seriously yet.

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #10075

### Context

Since now it is recommended to use Gradle daemon on CI machines we can benefit from running N instances of idle daemons instead of only one because usually CI agents build many projects at the same time and we can save a lot of time that we spent on starting new daemons if we have a pool of the daemons. The current strategy is not efficient for the CI agents because it kills all duplicated idle daemons except one after about 10 seconds.

This also may be useful when using Gradle to build projects remotely on one powerful machine. In this case, we need to have some pool of Gradle daemons in order to not spin them up each time.

nodes.body:
tl;dr

```kotlin
someTask.someProp.set("abc")
// becomes
someTask.someProp.value = "abc"

consumer.someInput.set(producer.someOutput)
// becomes
consume.someInput.source = producer.someOutput

someProp.get().asFile.writeText(otherProp.get())
// becomes
someProp.value.asFile.writeText(otherProp.value)
```

This is a proposal for some changes to to `Provider` and `Property`. Specifically:

- Add read-only `value` property to `Provider<T>` to represent the current value of the provider. This is the same as `get()`.
- Add mutable `value` property to `Property<T>` to allow the current value of the property to be set and queried. This is the same as `get()` and `set(T)`.
- Add mutable `source` property to `Property<T>` to allow the current _source_ of the property to be set. This is the same as `this` and `set(Provider<T>)`.

The intention is that `get()` and `set()` would be deprecated and replaced by these new methods.
None of these properties are nullable. Instead, a method to explicitly discard the value would be added (not included in this change yet).

The intention is also that the Groovy DSL convenience would be deprecated.

Similar changes would be made to the other property types. For example:

```kotlin
someTask.input.fileProvider(legacyTask.map { it.outputFile})
// becomes
someTask.input.fileSource = legacyTask.map { it.outputFile }
```

The `dependencies` block now supports adding a `Provider` type as a dependency to a configuration.

### Context

This allows plugins to create extensions that supply instances of `Provider<ExternalModuleDependency>`.

This is useful when you have a plugin that's `extension` can change what artifact is resolved.

For example:

```
dependencies {
    implementation(playDep.json()) // Becomes: 'com.typesafe.play:play-json_2.11:2.4.2
}
// This is declared later, so we need to support providers
play {
    platform {
        playVersion.set("2.4.2")
        scalaVersion.set("2.11.6")
    }
}
```

Fixes #11792

### Context
Improves the performance of DefaultExecutionPlan.hasOverlap by an order of magnitude when there are many items in both sets. For small sets, it got a bit slower in my tests, but this should be negligible I hope.

Detailed timings from my micro-benchmarks:
- 10 items x 10 items: before: 0.0004ms, after: 0.0009ms
- 10000 items x 10 items: before: 0.9ms, after: 0.9ms
- 10 items x 10000 items: before: 1ms, after: 1.6ms
- 10000 items x 10000 items: before: 604ms, after: 4ms

The timings even for the large sets are not as horrible as they were in #11792, so either the sets were even larger in my build, or the performance got worse due to long paths (I used rather short strings in my tests).

### Context

It's common for `META-INF` to contain changing attributes in `MANIFEST.MF` and properties files, and the current normalization method cannot be used either due to their impact on runtime behaviour, or non-stable filenames (for instance `<module-name>.properties`, so this makes their normalization a feature. 

In addition to allowing attributes to be ignored by key, for changing attributes such as `Created-By` (typically includes the exact JDK version), keys are sorted for comparison allowing keys to be order insensitive. Comments, whitespace and line-endings are also ignored by virtue of comparing the parsed representation of the files.

This specifically addresses the use case called out here:

https://guides.gradle.org/using-build-cache/#stable_task_inputs

And our info plugin that exposes build information in the manifest and `<module-name>.properties` files:

https://github.com/nebula-plugins/gradle-info-plugin

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #2669 for one class of scenarios.

### Context
<!--- Why do you believe many users will benefit from this change? -->
On the issue discussion page, a number of people have asked for an improvement in the parallel test scheduling, and even others who are not aware of it might be positively affected through shorter execution times.

The fix proposed here is to collect the test class runtime information from the previous test execution, and execute the tests sorted by duration, from longest to shortest. The actual change is small and seems to carry little danger (or even none?), and the central part of it (sorting test classes by size before allocation) has been proposed by the Gradle team themselves in the linked issue  #2669. I have combined it with a small (but noticeable) improvement of the vanilla round robin scheduling.

This change should have no impact when there is no size information available. This means that the main scenario in which this will be beneficial is one where duration information is available for most or many of the tests, e.g., reruns of test suites on not-swept workspaces. In an interactive setting, where you might be running `gradle test --tests xyz`, this will be of limited use. (But again, do no harm as compared to current behaviour.)

<!--- Link to relevant issues or forum discussions here -->
I have briefly examined the statistics of the current scheduling and the proposed improvement in a Juypter notebook: https://github.com/hansi-b/Long-Poles/blob/master/LongPoleTests.ipynb

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #11209

Currently, Jacoco defines two configurations for resolving tools, `jacocoAnt` and `jacocoAgent`. These are "legacy" configurations as they are both consumable and resolvable, which is deprecated as per the documentation.

https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/declaring_dependencies.html#sec:resolvable-consumable-configs

Thanks to @jjohannes help in #12016, I learned about these different types of configurations, and a generic way of applying platforms is to make sure they're applied to non-consumable configurations. I feel this is the best solution to my earlier issue, #11209 where I found applying a platform to jacoco configurations breaks the build. `withDependencies` behavior is great already for consumed configurations, and platforms can be applied to resolved ones.

Need help in how to properly deprecate the legacy configurations' `canBeResolved` flag

### Context

- Allows users to apply platforms to jacoco configurations if they would like to manage jacoco tool versions using platforms

While running JUnit5 parallel execution (or any similar parallel
execution, there can be multiple ProjectBuilder instances created
at the same time. If the static member has not been initialized
already in the class loader, there is a risk of duplicate class
definition taking place.

Fixes #11896

Signed-off-by: David Burström <david.burstrom@gmail.com>

### Context

In the right circumstances, parallel test execution can be a performance boost.

As for testing this fix, I looked into the integration tests but essentially the test
would have to run in its own class loader or as a separate test VM, and it would be probabilistic
at best, unless there are also changes in the production code to set join points in the if-clause. Please advise what you'd rather have me do, if this needs extra testing.
I have at least verified the behaviour on an affected project with a local build.

Previously, mapping from source files to class names was done by extracting
the class names from the class files names, which wasn't 100% accurate.
The Groovy incremental compiler, on the other hand, was implemented using
an AST transformation which could extract the class names from the compiler
itself, therefore giving an accurate mapping from class names to source files.

The same is now done for the Java compiler, using a Java compiler plugin.
This fixes several issues where we could not figure out properly what files
to recompile when the name of the class being used in a dependency wasn't
directly related to the source file name.

However, this introduces a problem when the compiler is not a proper JDK
compiler. In particular, if compiling using a "path to compiler", the
plugin cannot be loaded and incremental compilation will fail.

In an environment where ipv6 traffic for some reason is blocked on the
loopback addresses this makes it possible to force the use of ipv4 only

Set the GRADLE_FORCE_IPV4 environment variable to true to force usage of
ipv4 addresses only

Signed-off-by: Kenny Stridh <kenny.stridh@gmail.com>

<!--- The issue this PR addresses -->
Fixes #?

### Context
As discussed briefly with Volker Leak.

I have a problem (well the whole company) with a strangely configured VPN were all local IPV6 traffic is dropped by the firewall. After years of trying to change this within the company I would like to have this option in gradle instead.

The problem has a couple of symptoms
1. Unable to ping lock owner
2. Unable to communicate with already running daemon

Only tested it locally but the feature works as expected were all traffic is routed over ipv4 loopback instead of the ipv6 loopback.

Error messages prove to be difficult to interpret from a user point of
view. This commit tries to improve the situation by doing a couple of
things:

1. describing more clearly what the consumer is asking for. This includes,
when possible (currently only in the Java ecosystem), interpreting the
consumer attributes as a human-readable description, instead of a raw
list of attributes.
2. giving more context when possible. In particular, sometimes we fail
with an ambiguous variant error selection, but we only list the remaining
candidates, not listing the ones which were actually discarded during
selection. This proved to be particularly complex to debug from various
users (plugin authors and end-users).

nodes.body:
This change further explores the idea of providing an alternative to current script plugins by introducing a way to precompile script plugins, effectively turning them into binary plugins that can be used in the `plugins {}` block either from `buildSrc` or from the plugin portal after having been published.
The feature set aims to match that of [Kotlin's implementation](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/kotlin_dsl.html#kotdsl:precompiled_plugins) with a few exceptions mentioned below.

Based on this [spike](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/compare/gh/core/precompiled-scripts-spike).

### Overview

A new `precompiled-groovy-plugin` Gradle plugin is added that when applied will:
- discover any `*.gradle` scripts in `src/main/groovy` directory to be treated as Gradle plugins
- compile them in two phases: the plugins block and the body
- generate a Plugin class that will load the compiled class files and delegate the execution of those
- create the plugin metadata using `java-gradle-plugin` for each script

### Features

#### Plugin IDs
Plugin ID is determined from the script's filename. For file named `my-plugin.gradle`, the plugin ID is `my-plugin`. For file named `foo.bar.my-plugin.gradle` the plugin ID is `foo.bar.my-plugin`.

#### Packaging/Sharing
Precompiled Groovy plugins are packaged into a Jar and shareable like other regular plugins written against the Gradle API. They can be published and shared via an external repository like other plugins.

#### Cacheability
The task that compiles the plugins and generates the Plugin classes is cacheable and only needs to be rerun when the script contents change.

#### Testing
Functional tests can be written against precompiled plugins just like for regular plugins, no extra wiring needed.

### Differences from Kotlin's implementation
- Plugin ID is determined by file name only. Groovy scripts do not allow package declarations. Kotlin scripts can have package declarations.
- The feature is opt-in - in order for script plugins to be discovered, precompiled and wired up, `precompiled-groovy-plugin` plugin has to be applied. When using Kotlin DSL, `kotlin-dsl` plugin applies the precompiled scripts plugin implicitly.

### Shortcomings/Concerns
#### Backward compatibility
The plugins generated using this method will not be compatible with Gradle versions prior to this feature being released. This is because the generated Plugin class relies on a new `PreCompiledScriptRunner` class which is part of the implementation.

#### New internal API that should be kept stable across Gradle versions
The generated Plugin classes rely on `PreCompiledScriptRunner` to execute the precompiled scripts against the Gradle structures. Thus, this class introduces an API that should be kept stable going forward - if the interface of this class is changed, plugins built against a prior version and vice versa will break.
now that [the crashes are fixed](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/12457).

Before the 'release' property was ignored completely. The' targetCompatiblity' was always taken from the extension/convention and not from the task. Now we have the following setup which corresponds to how the compile task determines settings for the Java compiler:

- Use the release property of the task
- If that is not set, its conventions is the release property of the extension
- If that is not set, we take the targetCompatiblity of the task
- If that is not set, its convention is the targetCompatiblity of the extension/convention
- If that is not set, its convention is the current Java version

Follow up to: #12648

For example,

```
        tasks("test", "integTest", "crossVersionTest")
    }
```

There will be `core:quickTest`/`baseServices:quickTest` tasks, etc.
